ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of techniques used in molecular biology research. However, I did not learn very much about the underlying purposes at times.

By taking this course, I was able to become beyond prepared for the laboratory interning I will be doing over the summer. It was my first time taking a biology lab course and it truly went through almost all the necessary basic techniques needed for real life. For example, practicing micropipetting, gel electrophoresis, spectrophotometry, TOPO cloning, annotating using Lasergene, PCR amplification, Cas9 assays, and using electronic lab notebooks. These skills are essential to be applied to the lab.
I learned and/or strengthened foundational molecular biology lab techniques including AGE, PCR, and transformation.
How to work in a biology wet lab and use tools associated with bioinformatics.
I learned to do many molecular biology experiments and use softwares to do analyses.
I learned how to do basic biology lab skills. I also learned how to calculate basic concentrations for solutions.
This class really taught me a lot of molecular biology techniques like synthesis of guide RNA, primer design, how to analyze sequencing results, etc.
molecular bio lab skills
Learned valuable lab skills and scientific writing skills. Learned how a project is conducted
This class teaches students the common techniques and procedures used in a biology laboratory. Additionally students learn how to write a scientific research paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is fairly disorganized and has a disproportionately high workload relative to it being a half credit.

The strengths of this course include the fact that Professor Moreno and the teaching fellows were all invested in making the learning experience as smooth and as guided as possibly. Even though it might have been our first time ever trying some of these techniques their patience and teaching was direct and detailed. The course was also able to give me insight into the mannerisms I need for the lab in the real world and how it is best to keep everything organized.
A little disorganized. Did not know how I was being evaluated and assignments were sometimes a bit confusing.

Strengths: I learned a lot from the class. Feedback was clear. Teaching fellows were very supportive. Weaknesses: The syllabus could be clearer and updated more often; in the middle of the semester I didnt really know where the class was going.
There was not much work outside of class but sometimes the class went overtime or there wasn't as much preparation for some of the parts like guide RNA design took longer than expected

Pros: very useful and good feedback. Skills are relevant and well-taught 
Cons: Disorganized, but this is the nature of such a class; providing a more detailed tentative syllabus would help
While the content taught in the course is very valuable, sometimes the class could be difficult to follow and slightly disorganized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, this course is a lot of work and there are likely easier ways to learn about similar topics.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student who is thinking of interning at any laboratory at all. It truly gives you the perfect insight into how real-life circumstances are in labs. The course is great for fully understanding the purpose behind each laboratory technique and is important to investigating the detailed procedures behind preparing a CRISPR/Cas9 assay. It was a course well designed to bring you into what is expected in a biology lab.
Yes, good lab course. Interesting that it was project based.

Yes if you want to learn molecular biology techniques (or get half of a writing credit - Dr Moreno has another lab which is also half a WR!) Beware that the teaching is not so clear although Moreno is a great person.
I would recommend this class to peers who are are MCDB major or interested in ding biology research.
If you are a pre med who is just getting into research it could be good for experience
No
Yes but it can take up a lot of time. Make sure to plan well and to stay on top of your paper
I would recommend this course to students interested in doing biological research at Yale who do not have much previous experience.
